text: This video is brought to you by Dashlane.

Use the code lowspecgamer for a 10% discount
in you annual subcription.
My oh my Google Stadia.

It has been a while since I have seen the
release of anything in Gaming with this much

marketing money behind it and with such a…
interesting and often divided internet opinion.

Back when it was announced at GDC I was on
site both to try it out and parse out some

of the largest questions I had about this
upcoming service with the potential of changing
the industry for better, or for worse.

Since then details have surfaced, passions
have been flared on.

I had an opportunity to try a newer version
of the service during gamescom and that, combined

with some of the new details provide a clearer
view of what is the game google is playing
which has led to an interesting conclusions.

If you are with the group of people who are
raging at the existence of this service and

cloud gaming in general I believe that Stadia
is not meant for you and I mean that in the
most literal sense of the word:

You are not the target consumer in Google
plans and that begs the question… who is?

For those living under a rock and that refuse
to watch my older video about the topic, Stadia

is a game streaming service where games run
on custom hardware on a google server and
the video footage is piped to you via streaming.

This is on itself not a new concept, I have
explored on this channel a lot of the smaller

services trying a version of that with varying
degrees of success,

with 3 of them working very well when a stable
connection was maintained and no obscure technical
difficulties happened with the client.

However, decent cloud gaming was still arguably
an expensive option

at least until megacorporation Google decided
to enter the playground.

Google’s promise is: Gaming at highest graphical
settings, conveniently available any time,

in most devices with a strong internet connection
in a supported country with a small penalty

on latency since it takes time for inputs
to get from you to the server running the
game and back.

Google has promised they are leveraging the
vast expertise on video streaming and compression

technology not to eliminate latency entirely
but to create an experience where the user

does not necessarily feels it, as their GDC
developer talks (of which there is no public

video) focused on the metrics they are using
to alter the streaming algorithm to all sorts

of bad connection conditions to maximize user
satisfaction, the sort of technology that

only someone with deep pockets as google can
pull of.

However a large number of people in the most
avid gaming communities have raised very legitimate
concerns over Stadia centered around

the idea of games being un-accesible to modification,
access to games being controlled entirely

by a third party which means no game preservation
or ownership, lowering of game quality due

to video compression and bad latency and unrealistic
connection requirements.

Let’s start with the first point, the inability
to modify games, and let me rephrase something
that I touched upon my last Stadia video.

If you are the sort of person who build his
or her own PC to play games, or buys a prebuilt

or keeps up with new components and advancement
of Pcgaming you are very far from Stadia’s
target consumer.

People have again and again identified a lot
of the key things that you will not be able

to do with Stadia and these are all things that
can be said about Consoles.

Look at it this way, during their presentations
they straight up describe their value proposal
as:
Instead of needing to buy a console to play your games
We give you access to Google's powerful custom data centers.

Even on the booth material was like “Play
your favorite games without a console”.
Console,

I have been trying to find more marketing
material to make sure but I can’t find a single

time they have pitched this as an alternative
or competition to PC gaming.

But I think we can go more specific, I believe
Google’s plan is to take a chunk out of
a very specific part of the Console market.

Let’s look at the other points to show you
what I mean.

Access to games being controlled by a third
party.

Game preservation and ownership has been something
that has been negatively impacted over the

years as games become more digital, and we
can already see the consequences of that with

With some very interesting titles having almost
vanished from the gaming world and at least

on PC there are some measures that can and
are constantly taken to preserve some of these
games for the future

which inevitable opens up the topic of Piracy
and DRM which I do not have time to go into
right now and will leave for the future

but with games exclusive to Stadia there is absolutely
no way to conserve them if and when the service
stops operating... they are gone.

As a games enthusiast I am very concerned
about this but as a consumer I feel this is

a thing that only matter philosophically to
a smaller group and not of practical concern
to a lot of people that simply game.

Look at it this way, I have friends and colleagues
that are tremendous enthusiasts and authorities

on topics such as film or music, and people
in those circles possibly continuously look

at the increasing digital dominance of music
and movies as dangerous to the medium and

prefer to have their art in a physical preservable
form

I… like a lot of movies and a lot of music
but simply do not care about preserving them

enough to outweigh the convenience of just
having everything digital with the exception
of a very small number of collector items.

In that sense Stadia is for someone with an
approach to convenience over possession to

games similar to my approach to music and
movies

and this is not much of an speculation on
my part as the AMA by the Director of Product
of stadia makes it very clear.

To the credit of game preservationists…
it is easier to archive a digital only movie

or song for the future… than a game that
only exists via streaming with no access to
executable.

Although, again, this is also the case for
digital only games on console that usually

requires piles over piles of exploits and
hacks to be preserved.
It is just that in the case of Streaming it might just be entirely impossible

The whole one company controls your entire
game library aspect has a more practical issue

over game preservation, which is lack of trust
over buying games that only work on Stadia.

I feel a lot of people who raise concerns
over having all their games on a platform

that could go away tend to forget that specially
in the PC space we already have vast amount

of our libraries on digital only storefronts
that could still vanish overnight.

I don’t like this state of things either
but it is something we have collectively come
to accept for convenience and cost.

I think the real key difference is that at
least in PC space there is a certain amount

of variety or where you can get your games
and not a single point of failure shall a

service disappear, as there are plenty of
games that you can get from
steam, gog, uplay or… the… epic games store?
*Visual representation of the comment section on a video about Stadia that now mentions the epic game store*

In that sense Stadia is again more akin to
the growing digital sales of consoles, where

you have one storefront controlled by the
console’s company and no certainty that

the digital games you are purchasing will
work on the next version of the console.

But I think the core dissonance people are
feeling is that steam, sony or microsoft are

entities that have been around for so long
that we perceive them as stable and long lasting
versus

a service by google that has a very well earned
reputation of killing stuff when it is not
working out.

It makes people nervous to invest money into
an ecosystem when the company that manages

it might shut down pretty easily and I think
Google knows this and sort of its planning

around it which might explain the odd pricing
system.

Stadia has two price tiers, Stadia Pro which
is $10 a month for 4k streaming with access

to a growing number of games so something
more like game pass than netflix and a free
tier where all you need to buy is the games.

I believe this free tier is where the real
magic of their strategy is and I am surprised

there has not been more discussion about it
and the fact it is releasing later is very
telling.

Look at it this way, the pro tier which will
get access to the service soon is very likely

an early adopter strategy to test and build
confidence for this system to eventually create

enough of a feeling of stability to be able
to launch the free version with the possibly a
bit of better press.

But there is a lot more to be said about the
pricing and its timing so, save this point

in a box in your heard for a moment because
we are 100% returning to this later.

Let’s continue going through the list of
issues.

Let’s talk about loss of quality due to
latency or compression artifacting.

I tried Doom Ethernal and Mortal Kombat 11
working on Stadia on Gamescom thanks to YouTube.

As proof the enormous quantity of money Google
is pouring into this venture Stadia had one

the more slick and flash demo booth at Gamescom,
complete with constant trailers,
demo stations and a… slide?
That people were lining up to get into?

Every year YouTube tends to have a small lounge
area for certain creators in events like gamescom

but this year they integrated the YouTube
lounge with Stadia

to represent the deep integration that is
going to be between the two platforms.

Inside this lounge there were demo stations
for Stadia which meant an opportunity to test
thing calmy.

Which I can not show you directly because,
and here is the part that is insane, we were

not allowed to record any video that showed
the game.
So let me see if I got this straight.

If you are a YouTuber, the folks at YouTube
gaming are aware of you and you would already

be visiting gamescom you could get an invitation
email to the YouTube lounge.

A space with food, wifi and seats successfully
designed to facilitate the work of creators
recording video on the show whose exits

were constantly mobbed by people on the younger
side waiting for what I assume in some uber

popular fortnite youtuber to pop up and I
their

faces of disappointment every time I entered
or excited the booth will haunt me forever.
I got sidetracked again.

The point is, they had demo stations for stadia
inside this lounge to give creators a change

to preview the services… as long as we did
not record any gameplay.

I was told that this is because developers
had not provided authorization for recording

the games but I later found out the certain
select creators were both allowed and invited
to do videos on the service so… of course YouTube.

Some of the people invited to that were friends
of mine and I was really happy to see them
there, if a little jealous or irritated.

The worst part is, I spend a lot of time with
the Demos and they were fine.
Like, much better than expected.

There are obvious compression artifacts, the
game looks a high res youtube video which

some people might find horrible but for a
lot of people is fine.

Once it gets moving you forget about it pretty
quickly.

I forgot that I was trying out a streaming
demo.
There was an input latency when you actually tested  but not enough not be able to get used to it.

Now, fair point this is supposed to be running
on an off site demo but this is still super

controlled conditions on Google’s turf so
I look forward to a closer, independent test

on a less ideal environment but my preliminary
positive experience still provided a clearer
perspective on the possible future.

As I mentioned before on this video Stadia
is not only aimed at console gamers but squarely
at an specific segment of console gamers.

First, if you still hold the binary vision
of every gamer being just a hardcore person

that put a thousand hours into every game
and absolute casual

I have to at least point out that in 2019
there are many diverse groups of people playing

games passionately and participating in fandom
for different reasons.

The loyalist who has owned the same brand
of console for years, or the collector that

has a wall with all their game discs perfectly
ordered is likely not going to care about

Stadia at all and viceversa (I don’t think
google is trying to reach these people)

but in between these two sides there is a
pentora of people who care very much about
specific game or franchises but prefer convenience.

Right now a lot of these people already own
consoles and there is no practical reason

for them to suddenly switch to a platform
with a slightly worse experience.

In fact, as I mentioned before I believe the
pro tier launching this year is for early

adopters and technologically curious users
that are going to stress test the service

and provide valuable data towards the real
launch, which leads to immensely interesting
free plan.

Under stadia’s free plan users will be able
to use the service for free up to 1080p and

60 fps while only having to buy the games
which results as essentially a
“free”
next gen console.

It is not a coincidence that the launch date
for this is “sometime” next year,

just like the first round of next gen consoles
are coming “sometime” next year as well

and I will be very surprised if stadia is
not playing cat and mouse to launch their

free tier before but not very far from the
new consoles.

When the new generation rolls around lots
of these gamers will want access to the new

Fifa or the new call of duty and might have
to consider spending $400 on a new console
to do so…

they might realize that Google is giving them
a “console” for free which could allow

them to buy the game immediately and start
playing at once, and what I have seen in

terms of quality loss is probably acceptable
considering how convenient this whole thing is

This why it is not the exclusives the Stadia
is pushing so hard, but the fact that there

are going hard at making sure multiplatform
releases will also be coming to Stadia.
They are going for console parity

When that happens we might actually see the
turnaround that cloud gaming is promising.
So, is that it?

When the next console gen rolls around is
cloud gaming taking over and we can say goodbye
to game preservation and any user control?
What?
No!

Have you been listening to anything I have
been saying?

Stadia might become an important alternative
for a lot of people but it has a very specific

audience that is not enthusiast PC gamers,
collector, or console loyalist but this intermediate

sort of gamer that values convenience and
cost,

that lives on this very specific country list
and has both no data caps which are a big
problem in the US

and internet fast/stable enough to support
it.

This last point is still the last variable
left.

Google is promising the word regarding the
magic its algoritms can deliver, but if this
thing does not work well

on this level on someone’s ADSL phone connection
this whole value proposition comes tumbling
down.

I guess we will find out when Stadia finally
starts to roll out for the pro people soon
and I test it on my grandma’s internet.

This service is also likely to be very attractive
for lots of people stuck playing on low end

PCs purely due to lack to resources to buy
a console but as I have stated in the past

the list of countries available for the service
is lacking some of the bigger critical areas

of people that could use the stadia free plan
which might simply not have the infrastructure

to support this level of cloud gaming yet
but are growing markets for gaming such as
south america and Asia.

So even if being optimistic Stadia is not
taking over the world but likely becoming

a new more convenient free console of sorts
for developed countries

which is why their announcements seem so focused
on parity with multi-platform releases and

There is plenty of data supporting the fact
that gamers worldwide are growingly multi
platform which I totally get because…

I have a switch because when I am away from
my PC

I like playing fantasy dating simulator like
any decent man so

I will likely pick several games where I don’t
care about latency so much and I don’t care

about really owning the game long term and
have them on stadia for when I do not have

the patience to fiddle with hardware and want
to just play immediately.

The fact that really bother me about this
whole thing is that there is no way in hell

Google is making any money from the free Stadia
tier.

All this hardware and deployment is super
expensive and them giving them out for free

seems like more of the modern classic of mega
corporations burning through their infinite

stores of money to get us addicted to their
products and continue their dominance over
growing parts of our lives and…

considering how Google is starting to not
be shy about using the weight of their monopolies
around is concerning.

I mean, don’t you love having chunks of
your entire life centered around a single

account for your cyberpunk corporation of
your choosing?

Don’t you love the feeling that your entire
life could be destroyed if a single password
leaked?
Well, me neither

which is why I am continuously happy that
these videos are sponsored by Dashlane because

the rate at which my data is leaking this
year is not even funny any more and I like

not having a panic attack any time one of
my old passwords are figured out.

Dashlane is like a swiss army knife of security
services that integrates several tools
into one.

You have a VPN that you can use to secure
your connections over public wifi or get over
service geolocking,

you have leak alerts that lets you know when
one of your old passwords is published in
a pastebin somewhere and

you have password management that helps create
secure passwords for all your services and

manage them automatically, all stored in a
locally encrypted storage of which you are
the sole owner of the password,

so even if Dashlane gets hacked no one gets
access to your account all that is sync and

stored online is you encrypted storage, never
the master password.

Dashlane premium is less than $5 a month which
is much cheaper than getting 3 of those services

separately and if you use my link you can
get the first 30 days absolutely free and

if you like it, you can use the lowspecgamer
code after that to get 10% an annual subcription

and that is how you can let them know that
you came from this channel

I have said this a thousand times but it is
worth repeating because people don’t believe
this is not part of the sponsor read.

I use dashlane personally to keep track of
the increasing problem that has been my online

accounts and it keeps saving me from nasty
situations so really, it makes me super happy
that they are one of my sponsors.

Thank to them and you for watching all the
way here.
